Nigerian universities are battling outdated infrastructure, overcrowded lecture halls, and chronic underfunding.

By Gotom Golponer Haruna

Nigerian universities are grappling with serious challenges that threaten the quality of education and the future of the nation‚Äôs leaders. Outdated infrastructure, overcrowded lecture halls, and chronic underfunding have become the norm rather than the exception. Many institutions struggle with dilapidated buildings, insufficient classrooms, and outdated laboratories, making it difficult for students to learn effectively. Overcrowding exacerbates the problem, with lecture halls often filled beyond capacity, hindering student engagement and interaction. This environment is far from conducive to fostering innovation and critical thinking, which are essential for developing the next generation of leaders. Chronic underfunding worsens the situation, limiting universities‚Äô ability to hire qualified faculty, invest in research, and maintain basic facilities. The question is: how can Nigerian universities prepare future leaders when their learning environment is crumbling? Without urgent reforms and increased investment, the country risks producing graduates ill-equipped to face modern challenges. The government, private sector, and stakeholders must collaborate to revamp the education sector, improve infrastructure, boost funding, and ensure quality education is accessible to all.
